title: 108_hr1811
content: The "Family Opportunity Act of 2003" or the "Dylan Lee James Act" makes amendments to the Social Security Act. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2003" makes amendments to the Social Security Act, including opportunities for families of disabled children to purchase Medicaid coverage for such children. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2003" allows families of disabled children to purchase Medicaid coverage for those children under 18 years of age who are described as disabled children in the act. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2003" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 18 years of age who meet specific criteria related to disability and family income levels. The State may establish medical assistance for individuals with family income exceeding 250 percent of the poverty line using State funds only, with no Federal financial participation. Employer-sponsored family coverage under a group health plan is also addressed. The State may require parents to enroll in and pay premiums for family coverage under a group health plan as a condition for their child to remain eligible for medical assistance. If the parent's employer contributes at least 50 percent of the total cost of premiums, the State must reduce the premium imposed on the parent under certain conditions. The State may require parents to pay premiums for family coverage under a group health plan for a child with a disability. The State can also provide payment assistance for the annual premium. Additionally, there is an option for the State to impose income-related premiums for disabled children receiving medical assistance. With respect to disabled children receiving medical assistance, a State can require families to pay monthly premiums based on income, not exceeding 5% of the family's income. Premiums must be imposed consistently and eligibility cannot be terminated for non-payment. The State can require families to pay monthly premiums for medical assistance for disabled children, not exceeding 5% of the family's income. Premiums must be paid consistently, and eligibility cannot be terminated for non-payment unless the failure continues for at least 60 days. The State may waive payment in cases of undue hardship. Amendments made to Section 1903(f)(4) apply to medical assistance from October 1, 2005 onwards. SEC. 3. Treatment of inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. Section 1915(c) is amended to include coverage for inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. In paragraph (2)(C), coverage is expanded to include inpatient psychiatric hospital services for individuals under age 21 in home or community-based services waivers. Additionally, paragraph (7)(A) is amended to include individuals under age 21 who would require inpatient psychiatric hospital services. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply with respect to medical assistance provided on or after January 1, 2004. SEC. 4. DEVELOPMENT AND SUPPORT OF FAMILY-TO-FAMILY HEALTH INFORMATION CENTERS. Section 501 (42 U.S.C. 701) is amended to provide funding for special projects supporting family-to-family health information centers. $3,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2004, $4,000,000 for 2005, $5,000,000 for 2006, and $5,000,000 for each of 2007 and 2008. The family-to-family health information centers receive additional funding and remain available until expended. These centers assist families of children with disabilities in making informed health care choices, providing information on resources and successful health delivery models. The family-to-family health information centers aim to identify successful health delivery models for children with disabilities, collaborate with healthcare stakeholders, provide training and guidance, conduct outreach activities, and be staffed by families with expertise in healthcare systems. The family-to-family health information centers will be developed in at least 25 states in fiscal year 2004, 40 states in fiscal year 2005, and 50 states plus the District of Columbia in fiscal year 2006. The provisions applicable to funds for the Secretary under section 502(a)(1) also apply to funds under this subsection. The term 'State' refers to all 50 states and the District of Columbia. SEC. 5. Restoration of Medicaid eligibility for certain SSI beneficiaries. Amendment to Section 1902(a)(10)(A)(i)(II) of the Medicaid Act allows for Medicaid eligibility for individuals under 21 years old who would qualify for supplemental security income benefits. The effective date for these amendments is the first day of the first calendar quarter after the enactment of the Act.
